newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Woolworths back to double-digit qtr growth.
newsitem.headline: Woolworths back to double-digit qtr growth.

text.p: Australian retailer Woolworths Ltd reported a return to double-digit quarterly sales growth on Thursday, outperforming its expectations to post annual sales growth of 9.25 percent.
Chief executive officer Reg Clairs said the result, built on a progressive improvement throughout the year, was gratifying and showed some slight return of consumer confidence.
Woolworths three months ago was forecasting annual sales growth of about 8.5 percent.

Woolworths earlier reported its sales rose to A$15.57 billion in the 53 weeks ended June 29 from A$13.99 billion in the 52 weeks ended June 23, an unadjusted increase of 11.36 percent or 9.25 percent adjusted to a 52-week basis.
On a "like-for-like" basis, which excludes the impact of new stores, the sales increase over a 52-week period was 4.39 percent, Woolworths said.

"If there's an inflation rate of around 1.5 to 2.0 percent, to have achieved 4.4 percent is a particularly pleasing result and it does reflect that there is the slightest element of an improvement in consumer confidence," Clairs told Reuters.
Adjusting for the early Easter and excluding the additional week of trading gave quarterly sales rises of 8.2 percent, 8.9 percent, 9.2 percent and 10.8 percent, Clairs said.
"So it's back to double digits again," he said. "It's just progressively got stronger."
Woolworths enjoyed double-digit growth for most of the 1990s, but sales started to slow in 1995/96 as Australia's inflation rate fell and the retail environment became tougher.
Clairs said supermarket sales had benefited from new store openings, a full year's trading from the purchase of stores in Canberra, and retail petrol and wholesaling initiatives.

Woolworths has started selling petrol at some of its supermarkets and plans to open one new site a week for the next three years, eventually establishing about 200 sites by 2000. However, the Sydney-based retailer has only 12 retail petrol sites at present, and Clairs said the operations had not made a a significant contribution to sales.
Clairs said the second initiative, the Australian Independent Wholesalers (AIW) wholesaling arm, was building market share in Queensland and would open in Victoria in several weeks.
Woolworths hoped AIW would break even in about a year's time, he said.
Both petrol sales and wholesaling would be broken out from the supermarkets division next year.

Total food sales for 1996/97 rose 9.23 percent on a 52-week basis to A$13.35 billion, general merchandise sales were up 10.29 percent at A$1.82 billion, and specialty retail was up 5.54 percent at A$396 million.
Clairs said general merchandise sales were driven by the Big W group, which opened some new stores and pursued a strong marketing campaign.
There seemed to be "a little degree" of consumer confidence returning to discretionary spending, reflecting official interest rate cuts, he said.
But he declined to comment on interest rate policy.
